occurrences.line_text: Or gard her to defend from bold oppressors might.
That rather seem'd the conquest of his might,
That him not onely sought by open might
With so huge force, that seemed nothing might
And they her forth conducted, where they might
Him otherwise perswade, all that she might;
So faint and feeble were, that they ne might
For by no art, nor any leaches might
Vpon them two they fell with might and maine,
That maugre all their might, he did repell,
Wayting if he vnwares him murther might:
And layd at him amaine with all his will and might.
Which what it dare not doe by open might,
In which they mote make triall of their might,
Did bend their speares, and both with equall might
The whyles they strike at him with heedlesse might,
For that himselfe thereto did want sufficient might.
Where he himselfe might see his foeman slaine;
His trustie sword, the seruant of his might,
The picture of his punishment might see,
Did boast her beautie had such soueraine might,
That he might see his men, and muster them by oth.
Which wont doe suit and seruice to his might;
And maugre all his might, backe to relent:
So forcibly, that with his owne hands might
Ne would endure the daunger of their might,
That, were no might in man, nor heart in Knights,
Might them oppresse, and painefully turmoile,
To sad decay, that might contented liue.
Or that my fortunes might transposed bee
Ne ought there wanted, which for pleasure might
By which he might her to his loue allure,
That by his fellowship, he colour might
That euer liu'd, and th'onely glory of his might.
Albe with all their might those Brigants her did keepe.
Ne wight he found, to whom he might complaine,
Ne wight he found, of whom he might inquire;
How he might saue her life, if life did last;
Or if that dead, how he her death might wreake,
That he by them might certaine tydings weene
But Calidore with huge resistlesse might,
And fierce assayling him, with all their might
He her gan to recomfort, all he might,
For his great riches and his greater might.
Yet did that auncient matrone all she might,
Where he him fou[n]d despoyling all with maine & might.
Rencountred him with so impetuous might,
To be downe held, and maystred so with might,
To see the hatefull sunne, that he might tell
Thus was this Monster by the maystring might
To thinke how this long death thou mightest disinherit.
Y cladd in mightie armes and siluer shielde,
The Laurell, meed of mightie Conquerours
Who nought aghast, his mightie hand enhaunst:
And mightie causes wrought in heauen aboue,
For by his mightie science he could take
And mightie proud to humble weake does yield,
For he was strong, and of so mightie corse,
The house of mightie Prince it seemd to bee:
There also was that mightie Monarch layd
And mightie strong was turnd to feeble fraile.
His mightie armour, missing most at need;
Where fast embard in mightie brasen wall,
Vnwares surprised, and with mightie mall
Therefore, deare Sir, your mightie powres assay.
That when the knight beheld, his mightie shild
The mightie trunck halfe rent, with ragged rift
Of Saxon kings, that haue with mightie hand
At last his mightie ghost gan deepe to grone,
His mightie hands did on the madman lay,
Their mightie strokes their haberieons dismayld,
The mightie martiall hands doe most commend;
Though somewhat moued in his mightie hart,
Like mightie pillours, this fraile life of man,
That neither could his mightie puissance sustaine.
From mightie kings and conquerours in warre,
And therein haue their mightie empire raysd,
Of mightie GÃ¶emot, whom in stout fray
Vnto the mightie streame him to betake,
And mightie deeds, should matched haue the best:
From sea to sea he heapt a mightie mound,
Of these a mightie people shortly grew,
With mightie deedes their sundry gouernments;
Whose emptie place the mightie Oberon
Twixt his two mightie armes him vp he snatcht,
Yet life he saw, and felt his mightie maine,
Of mightie Magnes stone, whose craggie clift
For by his mightie Science he had seene
Ne ought the more their mightie strokes surceasse,
Or other mightie cause vs two did hither send.
A mightie man at armes, and mickle fame
One day of Proteus by his mightie spell,
His mightie waters to them buxome bee;
And yet remember well the mightie word,
Long so she on the mightie maine did flote,
And hath the charge of Neptunes mightie heard;
Vnder a mightie rocke, gainst which do raue
As it with mightie leuers had bene tore:
At last that mightie chaine, which round about
His mightie indignation did forbeare,
All mightie men and dreadfull derring dooers,
Full many mightie strokes on either side
Against so many no lesse mightie met,
Whereof full blith, eftsoones his mightie hand
Who vnderstanding by her mightie art,
A mightie speare eftsoones at him he bent;
And shun his mightie strokes, gainst which no armes auayled.
Which sory words her mightie hart did mate
Whom after did a mightie man pursew,
This mightie man (quoth he) whom you haue slaine,
And mightie kingdomes of his force adred;
Aswell which in the mightie Ocean trade,
Mightie Chrysaor, and Caicus strong;
And mightie Albion, father of the bold
That soueraine Queene, that mightie Emperesse,
Had neede haue mightie hands, for to fulfill
Much was she moued with the mightie sway
His mightie hands, the distaffe vile to hold,
To meeke obeysance of loues mightie raine,
The art of mightie words, that men can charme;
And mightie Conquerors, in royall state,
So did this mightie Ladie, when she saw
And humbly gan that mightie Queene entreat,
Appointed by that mightie Faerie Prince,
His mightie hart their mournefull case can rew,
He with him closd, and laying mightie hold
Three mightie en'mies did him most despight,
Three mightie ones, and cruell minded eeke,
The mightie ones, affrayd of euery chaunges dread.
And mighty spirites bound with mightier band,
By which the mightiest things efforced bin:
Who mightily vpheld that royall mace,
Who mightily that scepter did sustayne,
Their stedfast stonds did mightily maintaine,
So mightily the Briton Prince him rouzd
To strike his oares, and mightily doth driue
She mightily auentred towards one,
Most sacred fire, that burnest mightily
They shall vpreare, and mightily defend
But his sonne Malgo shall full mightily
But after him, Cadwallin mightily
So mightily she smote him, that to ground
Did him assayle, and mightily amate,
And their assault withstood so mightily,
For he was strong and mightily stiffe pight,
Great Gormond, hauing with huge mightinesse
Of wondrous worth, and eke of wondrous mights,
As farre exceeded men in their immeasurd mights.
Mo[N]Gst thousand dangers, & ten thousand magick mights.
Perdy thou peasant Knight, mightst rightly reed
He seekes out mighty charmes, to trouble sleepy mindes
In mighty armes he was yclad anon,
And to your mighty will. Her humblesse low
Of a most mighty king, most rich and sage;
A knight her met in mighty armes embost,
Amongst these mighty men were wemen mixt,
His rawbone armes, whose mighty brawned bowrs
Ne ought the powre of mighty men did dread
Such one, as that same mighty man of God,
Come gently, but not with that mighty rage,
By subtilty, nor slight, nor might, nor mighty charme.
To thee, most mighty king of Eden faire,
Right well I wote most mighty Soueraine,
When two so mighty warriours he dismade:
That more to mighty ha[n]ds, the[n] rightfull cause doth trust.
And to that mighty Princesse did complaine
Of him, what mighty warriour that mote bee,
Ne plate, ne male could ward so mighty throwes,
But to the mighty victour yields a bounteous feast.
And eue[r]more with mighty spels them charmd,
Twixt his two mighty armes engrasped fast,
She is the mighty Queene of Faerie,
Vpon a mighty furnace, burning whot,
Mighty Monoceroses, with immeasured tayles.
That art in mighty armes most magnifide
His mighty staffe, that could all charmes defeat:
Her mighty charmes, her furious louing fit,
A mighty Mazer bowle of wine was set,
Braue Captaines, and most mighty warriours,
Great aid thereto his mighty puissaunce,
And mighty people, dreaded more then all
Beside those armes there stood a mighty speare,
And mighty woods, which did the valley shade,
To yield himselfe vnto the mighty ill:
In minde to leape into the mighty maine,
He spide far off a mighty Giauntesse,
His mighty speare he couched warily,
To weet the mighty Ollyphant, that wrought
And girlond of the mighty Conquerours,
And far abroad his mighty branches threw,
So mighty be th'enchauntments, which the same do stay.
His mighty rage, and with imperious sway
On mighty kings and kesars, into thraldome brought.
The mighty Mars, to learne his wanton playes:
Of mighty Conquerours and Captaines strong,
Smart daunts not mighty harts, but makes them more to swell.
And heau'd his murdrous axe at him with mighty sway.
And mighty spirites bound with mightier band,
His mighty heart did almost rend in tway,
She sent an arrow forth with mighty draught,
His mighty limbs, whilest all with filthy bloud
That the displeasure of the mighty is
For well she wist now in a mighty hond,
His mighty heart with indignation sweld,
Was toucht, and mighty courage mollifide,
And makes them subiect to his mighty wrong;
To be a mirrour to all mighty men,
There they beheld a mighty Gyant stand
Ne any may his mighty will withstand;
For what the mighty Sea hath once possest,
His mighty hand to shend, he Talus sent
A goodly citty and a mighty one,
And euery while that mighty yron man,
Those mighty palmes, the which ye wont t'embrew
And mighty hands forget their manlinesse;
So whylome learnd that mighty Iewish swaine,
There is a mighty man, which wonnes here by
That thorough some more mighty enemies wrong,
And it hath long mayntaind with mighty wrong:
The whiles that mighty man did her demeane
And in his hand a mighty yron club he bore.
So mighty blowes, or proue the puissaunce of his pride.
But trembled vnderneath his mighty hand,
And bring into a mighty Peres displeasure,
More mild in beastly kind, then that her beastly foe.
But the faire Virgin was so meeke and mild,
All which, she of him tooke with countenance meeke and mild.
Vouchsafe with mild regard a wretches cace to heare.
With mild regard, to see his ruefull plight,
And doe in stead thereof mild curt'sie showe
And with thy mother milde come to mine ayde:
Be well aware, quoth then that Ladie milde,
Is not enough, that to this Ladie milde
Of milde demeanure, and rare courtesie,
But the milde air with season moderate
For th'aire was milde, and cleared was the skie,
But he endeuoured with speeches milde
For she was gentle, and of milde aspect,
Yet they endured all with patience milde,
Who them with speaches milde gan first disswade
Swift Proto, milde Eucrate, Thetis faire,
She did allure with gifts and speaches milde,
So milde humanity, and perfect gentle mynd.
In milder tearmes, as list them to deuise:
That they the mildest man aliue would make
Yet mildly him to purpose answered;
Her mildly answer'd; Beldame be not wroth
She chang'd that threatfull mood, & mildly gan entreat.
She to them made, with mildnesse virginall,
Which was from thence not past a mile or tway:
Who ere he thence had traueild many a mile,
So vp and downe he wandred many a mile,
Three miles it might be easie heard around,
They wasted had much way, and measurd many miles.
Thus many miles they two together wore,
To whom our sire, Milesio by name,
To milk their gotes, and make them cheese and bred,
And by her in a line a milke white lambe she lad.
And many drops of milke and bloud through it did spill.
And fostred vp with bitter milke of tine,
But certes was with milke of Wolues and Tygres fed.
And quilted vppon sattin white as milke,
And out of them to presse the milke: loue so much could.
Vpon that milke-white Palfreyes carkas fed,
And snowy neckd Doris, and milkewhite Galathï¿½a.
Do for the milkie mothers want complaine,
Vpon a milk-white Palfrey all alone,
The Birch for shaftes, the Sallow for the mill,
Like to a great Mill damb forth fiercely gusht,
Shall driue a Mill, within strong bancks is pent,
Against foule feends to aide vs millitant?
Fit mate for such a mincing mineon,
The noblest mind the best contentment has.
A virgin widow, whose deepe wounded mind
That moues more deare compassion of mind,
He to him lept, in mind to reaue his life,
Whose mind in meat and drinke was drowned so,
And nourish bloudy vengeaunce in his bitter mind.
And calles to mind his pourtraiture aliue,
They enuie her in their malitious mind,
Do chaunt sweet musick, to delight his mind:
And euermore in constant carefull mind
From that day forth I cast in carefull mind,
Musing full sadly in his sullein mind;
But his owne guiltie mind deseruing death.
O man haue mind of that last bitter throw;
His mind was full of spirituall repast,
Who him awaited still with pensiue mind.
Throwne out from womanish impatient mind?
And forth he fares full of malicious mind,
And if by lookes one may the mind aread,
And the weake mind with double woe torment?
But young Perissa was of other mind,
One that to bountie neuer cast his mind,
And wondred in his mind, what mote that monster make.
He was dismayed in his coward mind,
In mind to marke the beast. At which sad stowre,
But who his limbs with labours, and his mind
That my engreeued mind could find no rest,
Knotted in bloud and dust, for griefe of mind,
And now he has pourd out his idle mind
The wrath, which Atin kindled in his mind,
So easie was to quench his flamed mind
For to allure fraile mind to carelesse ease.
For the flit barke, obaying to her mind,
Or if to thy great mind, or greedy vew
Ensample be of mind intemperate,
The whiles the other Ladies mind their merry glee.
But full of Princely bounty and great mind,
But if the beautie of her mind ye knew,
Others to beare the same away did mind;
Pensiue I yeeld I am, and sad in mind,
Yet liuely vigour rested in his mind,
To which whiles absent he his mind did set,
A goodly creature, whom he deemd in mind
She will embosome deeper in your mind,
To sincke into his sence, nor mind affect,
Said Guyon, See the mind of beastly man,
Let Grill be Grill, and haue his hoggish mind,
The whiles faire Britomart, whose constant mind,
And chaste desires do nourish in your mind,
Mongst which it fell into that Faeries mind,
To slake your wrath, and mollifie your mind,
Or why make ye such Monster of your mind?
To loue the semblant pleasing most your mind,
Not so th'Arabian Myrrhe did set her mind;
So was their fortune good, though wicked were their mind.
But wicked fortune mine, though mind be good,
Full many wayes within her troubled mind,
A thousand thoughts she fashioned in her mind,
Loue my lewd Pilot hath a restlesse mind
His lustlesse limbes, and drowne his baser mind,
For whom he wondrous pensiue grew in mind,
The higher place in her Heroick mind:
Ne euer cast his mind to couet prayse,
And cast to loue her in his brutish mind;
But all his mind is set on mucky pelfe,
So huge a mind could not in lesser rest,
And seest euery secret of the mind;
In his disquiet mind was much dismayd:
Which was the dearest to his donghill mind,
In lofty lookes to hide an humble mind,
That counsell pleased not Malbeccoes mind;
That as a Snake, still lurked in his wounded mind.
Of all the passions in the mind thou vilest art.
She was emmoued in her noble mind,
Her earnest mind, yet wist not what it might intend.
As if in mind he somewhat had to say,
Which seene, he much reioyced in his cruell mind.
And maske her wounded mind, both did and sayd
That much she feard his mind would grow to some excesse.
His fickle mind full of inconstancie.
Beheld, eftsoones it prickt his wanton mind
He heav'd on high, in mind with that same blow
For in base mind nor friendship dwels nor enmity.
And thought in mind it shortly to amend:
And follow'd them, in mind her to haue reau'd
What equall torment to the griefe of mind,
She gan eftsoones it to her mind to call,
She inly were, and in her mind displeased.
And backe returned with right heauie mind,
Selfe to forget to mind another, is ouersight.
Yet nothing could my fixed mind remoue,
Did greatly solace his engrieued mind.
But when as nought according to his mind
T'expresse the meaning of the inward mind,
But of them all the band of vertuous mind
Vnlouely Proteus, missing to his mind
Her constant mind could moue at all he saw,
Which when his mother saw, she in her mind
The which afflicted his engrieued mind;
But rather gan in troubled mind deuize,
Or weigh the thought, that fro[m] mans mind doth flow.
But in the mind the doome of right must bee;
Much was the man confounded in his mind,
But if through stout disdaine of manly mind,
A sordid office for a mind so braue.
She gan to stoupe, and her proud mind conuert
Whom not my valour, but his owne braue mind
Voide of malitious mind, or foule offence.
But what so stonie mind (she then replyde)
(Sayd he) nor obstinate disdainefull mind,
Yet neuer meant he in his noble mind,
To beare vnto her loue the message of her mind.
The troublous passion of my pensiue mind,
They drew their swords, in mind to make amends
No easie meanes according to his mind.
To which whilest she lent her intentiue mind,
As tokens of her thankefull mind beseene,
Her mind so well, that to his will she bends
Then to his first emprize his mind he lent,
His wauering mind, yet to his aide agreed,
Much was the Ladie in her gentle mind
To shew her thankefull mind and meaning faine,
Which others, that haue greater skill in mind,
Much was I moued in indignant mind,
He gan in mind conceiue a fit reliefe
Euen so the baser mind it selfe displayes,
Be arguments of a vile donghill mind;
Yet in his mind malitious and ingrate
Though meane her lot, yet higher did her mind ascend.
As that he in his mind her worthy deemed,
Yet to occasion meanes, to worke his mind,
And in his mind with better reason cast,
But he, that in his mind had closely made
Resolv'd in minde all suddenly to win,
I gan refraine, in minde to slip away,
He chaungd his minde from one to other ill:
In her sonnes flesh, to minde reuengement,
But strifull minde, and diuerse qualitee
And to her weapon ran, in minde to gride
In minde to leape into the mighty maine,
Who all the night did minde his ioyous play:
That whylome in your minde wont to despise them all.
Him selfe, whose minde did trauell as with chylde,
That euen for griefe of minde he oft did grone,
Now gan he in his grieued minde deuise,
But he was soone aware of their ill minde,
But tossed in her troublous minde, what way
Her minde was whole possessed of one thought,
In minde he grew, for feare least by that art
A man of subtill wit and wicked minde,
As well as to her minde it had recourse.
The sence of man, and all his minde possesse,
And from her balefull minde all care he banished.
In whose pure minde, as in a mirrour sheene
The gentle minde by gentle deeds is knowne.
Forgetfull of her owne, to minde his feares:
Who both in minde, the which most grieueth me,
Sith he cannot expresse his simple minde,
Giue salues to euery sore, but counsell to the minde.
High minded Cleopatra, that with stroke
Whom when so lewdly minded Talus found,
At sight thereof his cruell minded hart
Three mightie ones, and cruell minded eeke,
These noble warriors, mindefull to pursew
He seekes out mighty charmes, to trouble sleepy mindes
Forgetfull of his owne, that mindes anothers cares.
Whose grieued mindes, which choler did englut,
For it the goodly peace of stayed mindes
According to their mindes like monstruous.
Hath troubled both your mindes with idle thought,
To banish sloth, that oft doth noble mindes annoy.
May nought at all their setled mindes remoue,
That should their mindes vp to deuotion call,
Hauing the mindes of men with fury fraught,
O Sacred hunger of ambitious mindes,
Into the mindes of mortall men doe well,
And in the mindes of men had great insight;
His mindes sad message backe vnto him sent;
And made vnfit to serue his lawlesse mindes behest.
He mindeth more, how he may be relieued
Of her aduenture mindfull for to bee.
But yet more mindfull of his honour deare,
Sir Guyon mindfull of his vow yplight,
Yet mindfull how he late by one was feld,
So nigh them, minding nought, but lustfull game,
Who minding more her safety then himselfe,
All mindlesse of the Golden fleece, which made them striue.
And eke all mindlesse of his owne deare Lord
All mindlesse of her wonted modestie,
And noble minds of yore allyed were,
In stoutest minds, and maketh monstrous warre;
Their minds to pleasure, & their mouthes to dainty fare.
To threat to him, that minds his chaunce t'abye?
And gazing wonder they their minds did fill;
Weake body well is chang'd for minds redoubled forse.
Their minds to praise, and cheualrous desire:
In brutish minds, and filthy lust inflame,
That ouer mortall minds hast so great might,
The saluage minds with skill of iust and trew;
The warlike minds, to learne her goodly lore,
Wonder it is to see, in diuerse minds,
But minds of mortall men are muchell mard,
To moderate stiffe minds, disposd to striue:
Thus whilest their minds were doubtfully distraught,
The cause of both, of both their minds depends;
Those be vnquiet thoughts, that carefull minds inuade.
The things that day most minds, at night doe most appeare.
Of noble minds deriued from aboue,
And to afflicted minds sweet rest and quiet sends.
With like fierce minds, but meanings different:
And how to please the minds of good and ill,
Ne once my minds vnmoued quiet grieue,
For trumpets sterne to chaunge mine Oaten reeds,
And with thy mother milde come to mine ayde:
The argument of mine afflicted stile:
I in defence of mine did likewise stand,
Mine, that did then shine as the Morning starre:
I saw before mine eyes, if I were knowne to stray.
For since mine eye your ioyous sight did mis,
Good cause of mine excuse; that mote ye please
That hath thee hither brought to taste mine yre?
Or thine the fault, or mine the error is,
Ioyous, to see his ymage in mine eye,
Go find some other play-fellowes, mine own sweet boy.
To tell the sad sight, which mine eies haue red:
Mine eyes no more on vanitie shall feed,
The which these reliques sad present vnto mine eie.
Then that I feele, and harbour in mine hart:
